ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better understanding of transition metal chemistry. Better appreciation for all the work that's brought us to our current understanding of inorganic chem. How to write an ACS-style scientific paper - this class has been more helpful than some English classes I've taken in teaching you how to write in a clear and succinct manner about complicated topics.
I learned how to write a scientific ACS style lab report and more about inorganic compounds, their syntheses, and electronic structures.
I learned how to write a lab report worthy of submission to a publication, synthesize my results to fit within a standardized report format, and relay science effectively.

I know that every lab says that they teach you how to write scientific reports, but this was the first time that I feel like the class lived up to that promise. I feel like my ability to write in a scientific way was much improved. 

Outside of writing, we got to do some cool things in lab and make compounds with pretty colors.
Common inorganic chemistry lab prodedures, reading H1 NMR, IR spectra, and UV vis data, writing scientifically styled lab reports.
Reading and writing scientific papers.
I learned a lot about writing in a scientific style as well as performing lab techniques.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - This class is well-organized, teaching you lab and writing techniques you'll use in your future as a scientist. I enjoyed the labs themselves (lots of pretty colors), I enjoyed the lab lectures (lots of fun science trivia), and I enjoyed writing the reports and digging deep into the literature. The written feedback on reports is incredibly thorough, thoughtful, and helpful, pointing out what you did well and where you could improve in the future. I grew a lot as a writer.

Weaknesses - Experiment 3 Report was one of the most difficult things I've ever put together (and this is including pchem lab reports). I think this report needs to be split up into 2 separate lab reports or require less data analysis. Or maybe more context needs to be given in the packet or in lecture. It was a lot to have to learn both how to use the computational clusters and also to figure out Tanabe-Sugano diagrams, not to mention that the workload overall was already x4 just bc of the sheer number of complexes we made and had to talk about. I'm proud of this report, and I learned a lot, but it was easily x4 the amount of hours put into any other report in this class.

The major strength is in learning how to write a lab report in the ACS style, which is far more complex and time consuming than typical lab reports for non-advanced classes. The major weakness was the lack of clear information in the syllabus. For all of the writing assignments in the course, there was no information about them or very little information given until they were about to happen. What the writing class consists of should be clearly demarcated at the beginning of the term so students know whether they want to take this class WR or not. The deadlines often changed for all assignments, but the communication was never made clear in advance. I also think Friday afternoon lecture is perhaps not the best time to have an engaging lecture with students, especially in a zoom format.

The strengths are the structure of these experiments. It is evident that these have all been carefully chosen and crafted by Professor Parr. I think lab 3 could be improved by being more explicit in what was required. I recall being overwhelmed by all the information we had to analyze and trying to write its narrative. A weakness is that there were also times when Professor Parr assumed I knew concepts but too much time had passed since I had learned them or I never actually did. Overall though, probably the best lab class I have taken at Yale.

This course is truly phenomenal. I enjoyed the experiments and Dr. Parr was engaging every step of the way. That being said, the workload for this course was very heavy. I think 3 lab reports, instead of 4, may have been more manageable, given the amount of calculations and writing involved in certain weeks.

It's a good lab class but the deadlines and organization were sometimes not ideal. Well often cover things necessary to write the lab report 4 days before its due which was quite annoying. There was not much guidance given on some assignments for the WR credit like the final review paper.

The strength of this course is Professor Parr and his comments on your lab reports. I've never received such clear and helpful feedback on any of my work since coming to Yale.

The course is fairly disorganized. It is very unclear when deadlines are, especially when the syllabus has dates on it that change all the time. Assignments are generally unclear. However, Parr gives very good, detailed feedback on your lab reports and you will actually improve your scientific writing by taking this course. However, if you are taking it for a WR, beware that the final assignment is quite extensive and it'll be very difficult to complete in the midst of your final lab report and other final exams.

I believe this course was taught extremely well, especially given COVID. One thing I found really helpful was that the lab classes were recorded, which allowed for not only flexibility with when I could watch the class, but more importantly allowed me to go back and watch videos for previous classes multiple times, which really helped when the material was technical or complicated, and my note taking in real time was not sufficient. My only issue with the class was that sometimes the schedule was not clear, and was not updated enough throughout the semester, but this is mostly only a problem for this semester because it was extra confusing with the break days.
Strengths--really interesting content, clear instructions, help always available if you ask, and very clear and detailed feedback on how to improve. No weaknesses!
This course was really good overall. The experiments were both interesting and pertinent to what was taught in Inorganic Chemistry.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was my favorite class this sem. We had an interactive in-person lab, and then Zoom lecture on Friday was also quite interactive and informative. There was a lot of info packed into those lectures, so I'm grateful that they were recorded and we had the opportunity to rewatch them; I think I ended rewatching one fo them more than 5 times.
the lab videos were quite helpful, even though they were done virtually - the afternoon lecture could have been more engaging, email response times could have been better.
COVID hardly affected this class I believe.

Dr. Parr's videos were excellent and engaging. The lab layout was COVID-19 safe and I felt I got good feedback both during the live portion of the class and virtual lectures. I don't think that any improvements are necessary for the course practices related to virtual engagement. I was very engaged!

Parr recorded lab sessions that were available to all who were taking the class. These were helpful for orienting myself with the upcoming lab and hearing his thought process, but it was an additional amount of work that I was not anticipating before taking this class.
Parr's transition to virtual lab was good in terms of resources, but sometimes it had felt like the virtual students were completely left in the dark.
The recoded video format for lab classes was really really helpful, as mentioned before. The labs themselves were also great (both safe and worthwhile)
The professor was very understanding and also the synchronous discussions were helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This is one of my favorite classes that I've taken in the chem dpt. The time spent in lab is fun, the lecture is engaging and interactive (though information-dense), and the 4 reports are fun and different, so it truly feels like you're learning something new every time. The workload is pretty spread out (except report 3, which took 4x the amount of time as any other report). The written feedback on reports is the most thorough I've ever received. I grew a lot as a writer and now even approach reading papers in a different way.
Yes, it's a good advanced lab to take - I would just make sure one is clear on all the assignments they are committing to doing before committing to the course itself.
Yes, it's the best chem lab in the department. It also has the most approachable experiments and lab reports.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Dr. Parr was a wonderful professor who is truly committed to student learning and enjoyment of chemistry. Additionally, the labs are fun and not too complicated, so you can get a good sense of the science behind each experiment.

I learned a good amount about writing, but I feel like oftentimes Parr wouldn't give the clearest guidance or explanation. For example, there was a lab where we had to use the computing clusters, and we almost nobody in the class could do it. Other times, Parr would talk about things in lecture that were just way above our heads.

100%.  The labs were really cool and I feel like I genuinely learned a lot regarding practical chemistry techniques and writing lab reports that emulate lab scientific papers in the real world. Also Dr. Parr is amazing and really really helpful in all regards. As far as chemistry classes for the chem major go this one has been hands down my favorite.

Yes! I really enjoyed it. The content was interesting and the lab reports, while time consuming, are manageable. I learned so much, and I know my scientific writing improved a lot with Dr. Parr's feedback.
Yes its a great lab.
If you are a chemistry major, I'd take this class both for the writing credit as well as what one learns about scientific writing.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Though I attended in-person lab, I was able to access the recorded lab videos online as well for those taking lab remotely - though completely optional, it was helpful to watch these before lab to get a better idea of set-up and implementation.
plus a once weekly live zoom lecture that was also recorded
There was an online Friday lecture on top of the in-person lab.
Weekly in-person lab and one live 50-minute lecture
In person lab once a week with a virtual live lecture once a week.
Canvas lab videos, Zoom lab classes, and in person labs
Virtual lab recordings with synchronous lecture meetings once a week.
also a live virtual lecture as well
